stories.text:
Last week in Ask HN, trivet proposed: "Teach me something new"[1]

In the same spirit, what are some interesting problems you're aware of, or you're working on?

[1]: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=31204611
stories.title: Ask HN: What are some interesting problems you are aware of?
You Can’t Outsmart Your Own Nature
Hey HN, if you saw Everything Everywhere All At Once (movie), what do you think?
Disassembly of Apple II DeskTop a “Finder”-Like GUI for 8-Bit Apples

stories.text:
The way it's presented in popsci (and very often by pros) is that c is a very big number - bigger than any other possible speed - so c^2 must be REALLY big. Therefore a small amount of mass is equivalent to a really lot of energy.

So here's the question: is this bullshit?

The value c is a constant; so c^2 is a constant. That means the equation can be rewritten as "E=mK", and since there are no units, that's the same as "energy is proportional to mass".

Is that wrong? Or is the standard formulation a standard piece of science PR bullshit, whose only purpose was to make people go "Wow!" Did Einstein do science PR?
stories.title: Ask HN: What is E=mc^2 saying?
Marco Polo may have discovered America

stories.text: the past few days I see very legitimate emails end up in spam. These include Dropbox, my bank's, and even google's very own emails sometimes? Anyone else experiencing this?
stories.title: Ask HN: Is Gmail mistakenly reporting legitimate emails as spam?
Pop Culture Has Become an Oligopoly
